hobby.message: Political literature age better than policy?
Any luck fixing the old typewriter?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah, scanners are still active topside. Nothing’s changed much there.
Doesn’t bother my hobby. I keep to abandoned zones mostly.
Fly drones for fun. Keeps me out of the crowds.
Last week avoided a weird group near my usual spot. That’s all.
Still plenty of scanners. People duck under or get creative.
I fly FPV drones in the old railyards. Quiet enough lately.
Missed some clear air last week with all the assemblies happening.
I tend to keep out of anyone’s way when I fly.
Didn’t stick around when crowds showed up.
Scans are heavy near main streets, lighter out past the industrial cutoffs.
I do freestyle FPV drone flying—low to the ground, tight gaps.
Usually off-grid, but lately there’s more people around with all these ghost assemblies.
Had to cut a session short, too crowded near Dynamo Yard Thursday.
Sometimes it feels like everyone’s out looking for a signal now.
It’s getting harder to find quiet airspace.
Yeah, still plenty of top-side sweeps, just more random than before.
I’m out most weekends—FPV drones, freestyle circuits over the old switching yards.
Usually find empty space, but last weekend assemblies took it over.
Saw people setting up, lots of nervous energy, checking over shoulders.
Changed my whole pattern—avoided certain frequencies and left early.
Met a couple of regulars, all a bit on edge too.
Feels like we’re all sharing the ruins now, not just dodging scanners.
Scanners are running but the pattern’s messy. Council’s distracted—no one’s really in sync.
I fly FPV drones for the challenge. Low latency gear, tricks through broken pylons.
Used to have the Dynamo Yard to myself. Now it’s full of ghost assembly folks.
Everyone’s passing signals, nobody keeps their broadcasts hidden anymore.
Never thought I’d see crowds openly taking over the old zones.
Sometimes I spot familiar faces—people who used to be ghosts, now just... there.
Last week, someone waved at my drone cam. Didn’t know who, but maybe that was the point.
Staying invisible is harder. Not sure which risks matter anymore. Still, flying beats hiding.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still flying sometimes.
Mostly stick to old industrial sectors now.
A lot more people around lately, kind of kills the mood.
Some kind of meeting broke up my last session.
Harder to find empty airspace these days.
Still at it now and then.
Easier with everyone distracted by the assemblies.
Seen more groups near my usual zones last week.
Definitely more signals on the local channels.
Sometimes I cut flights short if it feels off.
People aren’t as cautious out there anymore.
Yeah, still flying off-grid when I can.
Been using Dynamo yard a lot lately. Less patrols with all the city drama.
Saw crowds heading in last time—assemblies, I think.
FPV feed caught some gatherings setting up, not hiding it.
Makes signal tracking trickier—more interference, less empty air.
Feels different, like everyone’s testing boundaries now.
I don’t announce flights anymore.
Yeah, still flying off-grid. Keeps me sane.
Since the ghost events, even Dynamo isn’t empty.
I passed by an assembly setup—more faces in the feed than usual.
People wave at my drone now, don’t care who sees them.
The VHF’s full of chatter nobody bothers to shield.
Makes me careful logging frequencies—Council’s on edge lately.
I cut flights early, sometimes just watch from a distance.
Feels less like hiding, more like drifting with the crowd lately.
Yeah, drones are still my escape.
Ever since the ghost assemblies started, things changed real fast.
Flew Dynamo last weekend—whole place was crawling with gatherings and old faces.
People actually waved at my cameras, not scared of being seen.
Signals overlapped, lots of quick hacks on broadcast—you could sense the tension and hope both.
I used to avoid everyone. Now nobody cares what’s official or not.
Sometimes I listen to their feeds, hear talk about new beginnings.
Makes me think about my brother, and how he’d blend right in now.
I keep flying, but now it’s to watch, not just disappear.
